ORIGINAL POST:


I've never been good at making decent builds. They all fall short regarding sinergy. This is the first one I've made that somewhat makes sense and I just discovered a very similar legacy build, the Divine Warrior. Oh well, guess I'm not winning any originality awards anytime soon.

Either way, here it goes.

Character concept: "Talk softly and carry a big sword". This character enphatises using diplomacy (persuade) and talking things out before resorting to violence, however he makes sure that if things come to blows, he will be the last man standing.  This translates into a CHA-based melee paladin/CoT.

What this build is about: Using CHA bonuses to fuel Divine Might, divine Shiled and Smite/GReat Smite. It also has access to some paladin spells to add flavor and have some disposable buffs if needed. They idead was a melee build that gives the player something else to do than clicking on which thing you want to kill and watch the screen for the next rounds. so it has knockdown on top of that.

SKILLS SCHEDULE

At will. Personally I beleive that any melee build should try to maximize Discipline. Frothis build having a high score on Persuade is also a must, the remaining points can be used on heal, tumble, taunt, or whichever fits your playstyle.

*Great Cleave is there because there wasn't much to chose from. Could be ditched in favour of Iron Will, since it's the weakest save of this build.

**Depending on how this build has fared so far, you get to chose:
If you're taking lots of damage, take Armor Skin, or epic Toughness to increase hitpoints.
If you're not hitting things as often as you'd like, take Epic Prowess




SPELLS:

This build could perfectly do with less Pal leveles in favour of Fighter or -perhaps better yet- CoT. At level 22 you get two first level spell slots, two second level spells slots and one third level spell slots. Deafening clang should be on your prepared spells, as well as Bull's Strenght and Eagle's Splendor. Dispel magic is also nice to have to unbuff enemies. Failing that, Greater magic weapon.

TWEAKS I'VE CONSIDERED:

Drop WIS to 12 and increase CHA to 16. This would allow one to ditch one GREAT CHA in favour of one extra Great Smiting, ending still with the same stats. You'll lose the third level spell and a second slot on the second level spells.


THE GOOD:

20 turn undead to fuel DM/DS, 6 smite evil.

THE BAD:

Considering this is a sword and board build, it will nedd STR enhancing gear. A full plate plus a tower shield will spent almost all its weight capacity.

Eagerly waiting on comments and critiques of this build.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks for posting, Pelagius - I remember having to be cajoled and coaxed into posting my first build a couple of years ago - it's kind of terrifying. Now I post any old tat I come up with, so it gets better!

I'm afraid I'm got going to be much use in terms of full analysis - the last time I played a Pally was in Baldur's Gate, so am not even sure whether WIS or CHA governs their divine magic. However, from a melee-ist stance, it seems to me that you do need to boost your strength (or go a different route and play a finessed Dexer). Either way, I think you could either start with a better STR stat or sacrifice some of your CHA. Dropping DEX to 8, and WIS or CON to 12 (you've got Toughness to cover the HP difference) at the outset would enable a starting STR of 16. (If you were to take the CON reduction route, please don't be tempted to take Epic Toughness. Ever. There's almost always something better than that. An extra few HPs at that stage of your journey really shouldn't make any difference, while more AC or AB might.)

Please excuse me on this one, I may well have it wrong, but would it make more sense to take feats like Knockdown and WS before Extra Smiting/Turning? In early levels WS can make a huge difference, so I might be tempted to blast Fighter 1-4 before taking any Pally, but I refer you to the first sentence of my last paragraph as far as my knowledge of Pallys is concerned.

Regardless, someone sensible will be along soon...

Thanks again!

posts.author: Pelagius
posts.content:
Divine Might/Divine Shield are dependant on the CHA bonus. Smite evil too. So basically, if you wanna make a character who relies on those thigns, your CHA must be maximized at all times.

You're probably right about WS being probably better at earlier stages. Regarding KD, in my experience, is better once your AB is somewhat decent. Can't count how many times I failed a KD, when it really counted.

I assume that you meant to take Weapon Specialization at level 7.
As a replacement for Great Cleave, how about Improved Knockdown?

I may be displaying some ignorance here, but how would a build like this or Hip Maestro's compensate for such a low AB?

posts.author: Pelagius
posts.content:
Aye, my mistake. WS at level 7, not WF.

IK requires INT 13, so this build cannot achieve it, otherwise it would be a must.

Regarding AB, it's still a full 40 AB build (42 when using weaponf of choice and 43 if you take Epic Prowess), but it relies on STR enhancing gear to get past that, failing that, magic weapons. It shouldn't be that much of a problem because ogre strength gauntlets and belts of strength seem to be very common on most modules.

So,basically, it shouldn't be too hard to get STR to18 or more in the teens, add divine might to that and not only you'll be hitting stuff but adding heaps of damage that ignore damage reduction or inmunities.

Anyway, I don't think this build AB is that bad considering it's still full AB progression.

Since I normally play SP, PvM, I tend to favour well-rounded characters over min-maxed ones, and dislike havind abilities with negative bonuses.

I guess you could do dropping CON and WIS to 12, as Stagmeister suggested, or even settling for a final score of CHA of 30 (although this would get you GS later) to allocate more points on STR.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Well, I've now read Maximillian Kane's The Holy Class: A Guide to Paladins in the Game Guides forum, together with Hip's The Plight of Smite: Smite Evil Variants on page 4 of the Full Epic forum (for some reason), and I might want to revise my advice in light of those, given that this is definitely a smite-based build rather than an AB-based one.

Thus, the starting stats seem fine - if anything, I'd now think about losing 2 from CON and putting it into INT, because - while I haven't worked out how many skill points you'll have - I'm guessing you're going to be fairly skill-starved. This matters because as well as max-ing Discipline and Persuade, Taunt would be very useful in assisting with your AB, and you'll also want a detection skill - Spot or Listen - or you won't have time to buff/prepare before a baddy surprises you. If you were to max these 4 skills, that's 172 points before any others can be considered. Now, I don't know how many points a Pally gets, but with INT of 10, 22 levels of CoT netts you 44 points and the 4 levels of Fighter bring a mighty 14 points. That's a total of 58, which is less than ideal. Even with INT of 12 that's only another 43 points, so unless 12 levels of Pally brings 71 or more points (in other words 6 points per level), it's going to be a struggle. Actually, just noticed, you have 24 levels of CoT, not the stated 22, which pulls in another 4 skill points (YAY!). Oh, and I'd be taking that final level of Pally later in the build anyway, for a final Persuade and/or Taunt dump.

Hope this makes some sense!

EDIT: Just checked on Pally skill points, and they're the same as CoT and Fighter - 2+INT modifier. Thus, with an INT of 10, you'd have a total of 86 skill points: that's two maxed skills only, so I would really consider boosting your INT to at least 12, 14 would be better, but I understand what you say about not wanting a negative stat so you don't want to drop DEX to 8.

posts.author: Pelagius
posts.content:
Yep, as I said, I'm pretty bad at coming with decent builds. I tend to focus more on feats and overlook skills. Never used taunt, but on a CHA based build, it could come in handy.

Increasing INT to 14 would not only help with skill points, but also gives access to IK.

Mmm... back to the drawing table for this one...

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Not at all, Pelagius - there's nothing wrong with the concept - this is just tweaking!

As far as feats and skills go, I was much the same when I started building (sorry, that makes me sound better than I am, 'cos I'm still very much on the nursery slopes). Messrs Dagger and Hip (those two in particular, but others were active as well) were responsible for opening my eyes to the importance of skill points - tumble raising AC by up to 8, spellcraft boosting saves vs spells by up to 8, concentration enabling one to resist taunts, UMD enabling use of all sorts of stuff you couldn't otherwise, etc, etc...

I'll confess that I haven't used taunt much myself, but Max's Guide made was very helpful in that regard - give it a once-over if you haven't already.

IKD would also enable you to bin the GCleave malarkey as well - every one a winner! (Can't remember if Expertise is INT or DEX governed, or might think about as well)

Cheers

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Okay, time for some constructive criticism,

First, you should add a number after each line of your build, right after the class so we can easily see what's going on.
For example your first line becomes: 01: Fighter (01): weapon focus: longsword, power attack, cleave

Secondly, your build - if i counted right - has 24 levels of CoT and not 22.
The two last CoT levels give you no substantial advantage, you can swap them for two more fighter levels in order to get both "Armour Skin" and "Epic Prowess".
Thus your build becomes (fighter 6/ paladin 12/ cot 22).

Thirdly, you should consider optimizing your stats further. Paladin is a MAD class (Multiple Attribute Dependant) and has no room for niceties like 10 Dexterity or the like.
Especially so, in a "Great Smiter" build.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Good catch, hunearo! That means a further 43 points, so you might get away with 12 INT if you really want to, with maxed Disc, Persuade, Taunt and Spot (CoT doesn't have Listen as a class skill). The further 43 points that INT 14 brings would enable you to cross-class 20 levels of Tumble for +4 to your AC (more than making up for starting DEX at 8), or do the same with Spellcraft (18 levels, giving a nett 20) for +4 saves vs spells.

As hunearo also clarifies, you'd have access to Expertise as well, which might be of greater value than IKD, depending where you play.

Oh, and just to throw something else into the mix, it would be possible to drop starting WIS down to 13 and bring it up to 14 by an epic CoT bonus feat in Great WIS. I'm not saying you should, but you could...

posts.author: Pelagius
posts.content:
Thanks, guys. I must recognize that most of the improvements came from you all.

It occurs to me that there's another tweak that could be implemented in this build: ditching the last two Great CHA in faouvr of two Great Smites. At level 40 this means a loss of a +1 bonus on CHA.

Currently this builds adds 144 damage to smites at level 40, with this tweak it would add 216.

So one would have to consider if 216 damage vs 144 compensates:

-The loss of one turn undead (which also fuels DM/DS which this character is reliant on) from 20 to 19
-The loss of one round on DM/DS duration
-A slightly less powerful turn undead
-A skill check point loss on persuade and taunt

I guess it's not a bad deal. I've seen CHA based builds which top at 26-28, so dropping this one back to 30 to get more Great Smites sounds aceptable.

posts.author: hunearo
posts.content: And don't forget the loss of 1 AB on your smites.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
From a powerbuild viewpoint, it is definitely worth it.
Right now you are dishing out 170 (5X34) smite damage per hit or 510 if you go full burst mode on a boss.
With great smite VI though the numbers go up significantly, to 238 (7X34) or 714 dmg on a full burst. And that doesn't even count the possible critical hits!
You will be a freaking wrecking ball against anything evil, should you want it. Liches, Demons, Evil Dragons? You name it.
Your charisma will still be more than enough considering that in-game it will be enhanced by as much as 12 more points, to a max of (42).

posts.author: Pelagius
posts.content:
Seems a good trade-off to me. Even accounting for the 1 loss on AB on smites.

The good thing is that you can perfectly decide once you're there. No need to take that decision now.

I guess you could ditch Armor Skin and Epic Prowess for GS and still get 2 extra Great CHA on bonus feats, netting a final score of 32 CHA and better GS due to the +1 CHA bonus. It depends on if you wanna focus more on GS or rounding up the build.

Mmm.. wait a minute here...

Smite Evil adds the CHA bonus to the attack roll and the class level to damage, that means a pal 12 CoT 22 and a pal 10 CoT 26 will have the same damage output. Now, the loss of +1 to that attack roll by going 30 CHA can be compensated by the +1 from Epic Prowess,  a +1 that will apply to all attacks, not just the smites... and a loss of +1 to CHA based skills (taunt and persuade) doesn't seem that much of a deal...

Forget about the alt route. I beleive Demos has just given me the last extra improvement for this build. I have to dicht Valefor's suggestion of two extra levels of fighter, but I beleive this improves the build overall.

If this is the definitive version, imight polish the format a bit and re-pos it on the Epic builds. What do you guys think?
